Fairy Tales.Description: Recorded for children with or without background music.

Folktales.Description: Traditional stories passed down throughout many generations.

Guided Meditation.Description: Practice wherein an instructor guides the listener through the process of meditation throughout a session.

Interview.Description: Recording of a specific person/s during a formal conversation arranged for historical archiving or media broadcast, often in a question and answer format in which the interviewee shares their views and personal anecdotes with the audience.

Lectures.Description: Oral presentation with the intention to educate the audience on a specific topic.

Poetry.Description: Encompasses many forms of literature that use style and rhythm to evoke ideas and emotions further than the prosaic meaning of the literature itself.

Beat Poetry.Description: Stream-of-consciousness Poetry originating with the Beats in the 1950s.

Cowboy Poetry.Description: Descended from the oral traditions of cowboys and ranchers, written with traditional use of rhyme and meter, using humor and slang, and primarily concerning the cowboy profession, lifestyle, and legacy.

Dub Poetry.Description: Performance of Poetry over Reggae and Dub rhythms, which originated in Jamaica in the 1970s.

Jazz Poetry.Description: Emerged in the 1920s, incorporating the style and rhythms of Jazz as both art forms spread throughout African-American communities in the United States.

Slam Poetry.Description: Developed in the US during the late 1980s and early 1990s with the growing popularity of poetry slams, a form of poetry competition in which competing performers recite poems in front of a crowd.

Sound Poetry.Description: Emphasis is placed upon phonetics and the sounds of syllables rather than the meaning of the words themselves.

Radio Drama.Description: Narrative storytelling performed by voice actors and produced for radio broadcasting or published on audio media such as tapes or CDs.

Speeches.Description: Rhetorical acts performed publicly wherein a speaker typically monologues around a particular topic.

Stand-Up Comedy.Description: Comedy where the performer speaks directly to their intended audience, with origins beginning in the late 19th century.
